Rep. Don Bacon and Rep. Ro Khanna introduced the bipartisan 'No Coffee Tax Act' in September 2025 to exempt coffee products from tariffs, signaling potential legislative response to the issue.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Tariffs on coffee imports were implemented starting in July 2025, with Brazil facing a 50% duty, Vietnam 20%, and Colombia 10%, leading to increased costs for roasters and consumers.

keyTakeAways: The Trump administration's tariffs on coffee imports — particularly a 50% duty on Brazil, 20% on Vietnam, and 10% on Colombia — have significantly increased the cost of coffee beans for U.S. roasters.
The U.S. imports over 99% of its coffee, with Brazil (30.7%), Colombia (18.3%), and Vietnam (6.6%) being the primary sources.
Retail coffee prices rose nearly 21% in August 2025 compared to the previous year, with a standard hot coffee in Washington, DC averaging $4.21 (up 4%) and cold brew at $5.35 (up 3.7%).

Small and medium-sized coffee roasters like Swing’s Coffee Roasters, Vigilante Coffee Company, and Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting are experiencing higher input costs, leading to increased prices for consumers and financial strain.
Some roasters are exploring diversification of suppliers to mitigate tariff risks, while others, like Doug Ilg, have shifted away from Brazilian beans due to high tariffs.
Consumers may shift brands or look for deals, but coffee is seen as an affordable luxury, so changes in price are unlikely to drastically alter consumption habits.
The bipartisan 'No Coffee Tax Act' was introduced in September 2025 to exempt coffee products from tariffs, offering potential policy relief.
Economists like Erin McLaughlin note that the uncertainty and rising costs are placing additional pressure on small businesses and making long-term planning difficult.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Trump administration’s imposition of steep tariffs on coffee imports — including a 50% duty on Brazil, 20% on Vietnam, and 10% on Colombia — has led to significant cost increases for U.S. coffee roasters. As the U.S. imports over 99% of its coffee, these tariffs are directly impacting retail prices, with average coffee prices at restaurants and shops rising by nearly 21% in August 2025. Businesses like Swing’s Coffee Roasters, Vigilante Coffee Company, and Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting report higher bean costs and operational strain, prompting some to diversify suppliers. While consumers may shift brands or seek deals, coffee remains perceived as an affordable luxury, so consumption habits are not expected to change drastically. In response, bipartisan lawmakers introduced the 'No Coffee Tax Act' in September 2025 to exempt coffee products from tariffs, offering a potential policy solution to this growing issue.
title: Trump’s tariffs are brewing trouble for coffee roasters
